''citrinopileatus'' (Singer) Ohira (1987) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Pleurotus citrinopileatus'' | whichGills = decurrent | capShape = flat | capShape2 = depressed | hymeniumType = gills | stipeCharacter = bare | ecologicalType = saprotrophic | sporePrintColor = pink | howEdible = choice }} '''''Pleurotus citrinopileatus''''', the '''golden oyster mushroom''' (''tamogitake'' in [[Japanese language|Japanese]]), is an [[edible mushroom|edible]] [[Agaricales|gilled]] [[fungi|fungus]]. Native to eastern [[Russia]], northern [[China]], and [[Japan]], the golden oyster mushroom is very closely related to ''[[Pleurotus cornucopiae|P. cornucopiae]]'' of [[Europe]], with some authors considering them to be at the rank of [[subspecies]].{{cite journal |url=http://rms1.agsearch.agropedia.affrc.go.jp/contents/JASI/pdf/society/47-0967.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722104933/http://rms1.agsearch.agropedia.affrc.go.jp/contents/JASI/pdf/society/47-0967.pdf |url-status=dead |archive-date=2011-07-22 |title=A revision of the taxonomic status of ''Pleurotus citrinopileatus'' |first=Ikuo |last=Ohira |journal=Reports of the Tottori Mycological Institute |volume=28 |pages=143–150 |year=1990 }} In far eastern Russia, ''P. citrinopileatus'', they are called ''iI'mak'', is one of the most popular wild edible mushrooms. ==Description== The [[Basidiocarp|fruiting bodies]] of ''P. citrinopileatus'' grow in clusters of bright yellow to golden brown [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]]s with a velvety, dry surface texture. Caps range from {{convert|20|-|65|mm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter. The flesh is thin and white, with a mild taste and without a strong smell. [[Stipe (mycology)|Stem]]s are cylindrical, white in color, often curved or bent, and about {{convert|20|–|50|mm|in|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|2|–|8|mm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter. The [[Lamella (mycology)|gill]]s are white, closely spaced, and run down the stem. The [[spore]]s of the golden oyster mushroom are cylindrical or elliptical in shape, smooth, hyaline, amyloid, and measure 6-9 by 2–3.5 micrometres.{{cite journal| journal=[[British Mycological Society|Mycologist]]| volume=1| issue=3|date=July 1987| pages=106–107| doi=10.1016/S0269-915X(87)80076-9| title=''Pleurotus citrinopileatus'', one of the favourites| first=Erast| last=Parmasto}} ==Ecology== The golden oyster mushroom, like other species of oyster mushroom, is a [[wood-decay fungus]]. In the wild, ''P. citrinopileatus'' most commonly decays [[hardwood]]s such as [[elm]]. Spores are spread by ''[[Callipogon relictus]]'', a beetle. ==Uses== Golden oyster mushrooms are cultivated commercially, usually on a medium of grain, straw, or sawdust.{{cite book| first=Paul| last=Stamets| title=Growing gourmet and medicinal mushrooms| publisher=Ten Speed Press| year=2000| isbn=1-58008-175-4| pages=274–289}} ''Pleurotus'' species are some of the most commonly cultivated mushrooms, particularly in China, due to their ease of cultivation and their ability to convert 100 g of organic refuse into 50-70 g of fresh mushrooms.{{cite book| title=Mushrooms: cultivation, nutritional value, medicinal effect, and environmental impact| first=Shu-ting| chapter=''Pleurotus'' — A Mushroom of Broad Adaptability| last=Chang| first2=Philip G.| last2=Miles| publisher=CRC Press| year=2004| pages=315–325| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XO4EGzpp1M0C| isbn=978-0-8493-1043-0| edition=2nd}} ''P. citrinopileatus'' mushrooms are a source of [[antioxidant]]s.{{cite journal| title=Antioxidant properties of three extracts from ''Pleurotus citrinopileatus''| author=Yu-Ling Lee| author2=Gi-Wei Huang| author3=Zeng-Chin Liang| author4=Jeng-Leun Mau| last-author-amp=yes| journal=LWT - Food Science and Technology| volume=40| issue=5|date=June 2007| pages=823–833| doi=10.1016/j.lwt.2006.04.002}} Extracts from ''P. citrinopileatus'' have been studied for their [[anti-diabetic medication|antihyperglycemic]] properties, decreasing [[blood sugar]] levels in [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetic]] [[laboratory rat|rat]]s.{{cite journal| journal=Applied Microbiology and Biotechnology| volume=70| number=1| pages=107–113 |doi=10.1007/s00253-005-0043-5| title=Antihyperglycemic effect of polysaccharide from fermented broth of ''Pleurotus citrinopileatus''| author=Shu-Hui Hu| author2=Jinn-Chyi Wang| author3=Juang-Lin Lien| author4=Ean-Tun Liaw| author5=Min-Yen Lee| last-author-amp=yes|date=March 2006| pmid=16001252}} They have also been studied as a source of [[hypolipidemic agent|lipid-lowering drug]]s;{{cite journal| title=Antihyperlipidemic and Antioxidant Effects of Extracts from ''Pleurotus citrinopileatus''| author=Shu Hui Hu| author2=Zeng Chin Liang| author3=Yi Chen Chia| author4=Juang Lin Lien| author5=Ker Shaw Chen| author6=Min Yen Lee| author7=Jinn Chyi Wang| last-author-amp=yes| journal=Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry| year=2006| volume=54| number=6| pages=2103–2110| doi=10.1021/jf052890d| pmid=16536582}} ''[[Pleurotus ostreatus|P. ostreatus]]'', a related oyster mushroom, has been found to contain the cholesterol-lowering drug [[lovastatin]].{{Cite journal | vauthors = Gunde-Cimerman N, Cimerman A| title = ''Pleurotus'' fruiting bodies contain the inhibitor of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A reductase-lovastatin| journal = Exp.
